subject: Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: There really is no room for misunderstanding here. The term phoneme is a technical one, having a precise meaning. If you use the established term, you must
messageBody:
There really is no room for misunderstanding here.

The term 'phoneme' is a technical one, having a precise meaning.

If you use the established term, you must accept the established
meaning. If you wish to mean something else, then either use another
word (possibly created) or deal with the confusion you have caused.

Check out: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoneme

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "paulhtremblay" wrote:
> Here we are going to have to respectfully disagree. That is not my
> understanding of a phoneme. A phoneme is not an abstraction of a
> sound. It is the physical way that sound is represented, for example
> in speech or in sign language. When the Irish pronunce that differeent
> sound and attach meaning to that sound that we non-Irish cannot
> understand, then they use a different phoneme. Just because their
> phoneme matches a non Irish phoneme does not make it the same.
